thread.title: Petition to force U.S. trade bank renewal vote in House advances
thread.title_full: Petition to force U.S. trade bank renewal vote in House advances | Reuters

author: David Lawder
title: Petition to force U.S. trade bank renewal vote in House advances
text:
WASHINGTON A U.S. House of Representatives petition to revive the U.S. Export-Import Bank drew 218 signatures on Friday, enough to force a vote on the issue as early as Oct. 26, but the effort was likely to stall in the Senate.
The effort effectively overrules House Financial Services Committee Chairman Jeb Hensarling, who has declined to move legislation to renew the trade bank's charter, which expired on June 30.
Hensarling warned that the move sets a "very dangerous precedent" for the party. Some 42 Republicans had signed the so-called "discharge petition."
"At a time when our Republican conference is divided, this will divide it even further," Hensarling said in a statement.
While the petition and subsequent House floor vote would demonstrate that a majority of the House wants to renew the charter for the U.S. export credit, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has already rejected taking up the measure.
McConnell is opposed to keeping the trade bank open, siding with Hensarling and other Republican conservative critics who charge that the 81-year-old institution provides "corporate welfare" to massive, wealthy companies such as Boeing, Caterpillar and General Electric.
"The Senate is not going to spend a week on a bill that the leader doesnâ€™t support," said McConnell's spokesman, Don Stewart, when asked about the petition on Friday.
It may be still possible, however, for EXIM backers in Congress to attach a renewal measure to a bill to extend transportation funding that will be needed by the end of October. The Senate approved a similar measure in July as part of a longer-term transportation bill, but this was never taken up by the House.
(Reporting By David Lawder; Editing by Susan Heavey and Doina Chiacu )
